content.content: Hey all, YFI-A vault type debt ceiling is maxed out and the community needs to decide what to do next. I noted here that we already need to increase fees from the current 4% to at least 7% according to risk premium calculations based on our model. If we were to increase DC for another 10m or more, fees might need to be slowly increased into double digit territory. Although we estimated maximum DC to be 46m DAI, the current structure of vaults is seen as very risky as there is one vault with 11.5m DAI debt that has only 204% collateralization (14% price drop and it gets liquidated). However this vault seems to be quite sophisticated and avoided liquidations a few times last week. In the last Signal YFI-A DC increase to 30m has won. There are few possibilities how to move ahead so I am going to list them here.  Increase DC to 30m, but also increase SF to 10%. Create YFI-B with a LR of 225%. Such vault type could have another 20m DC applied with a SF closer to what it is now (4%). Whitelisted vaults? We haven’t heard from the SC team if this is doable in a short term and also what it implies for Maker offering such products. Leave DC at 20m and increase SF to 7%. Some might feel the whole situation is too risky to additionally increase DC.  Note that despite the outcome here I am going to propose to increase YFI-A SF to 7% when we have a Rates Group meeting next week. Which step should we take forward regarding YFI vaults?     Increase DC to 30m and SF to 10% Create YFI-B with 225% LR / 20m DC / 4% SF Whitelisted vaults when available Leave DC at 20m and increase SF to 7% Other - Comment below Abstain     0 voters     Poll will remain open until this Friday December 4th and the winner will proceed to on-chain poll next week (including proposed SF increase to 7% for YFI-A if options 2 or 3 win)
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post is explaining the current situation of the YFI-A vault type debt ceiling being maxed out and the need for the community to decide on the next steps. The author lists several possibilities for moving forward and proposes to increase YFI-A SF to 7% in the next Rates Group meeting. The post also invites feedback and suggestions from the community.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: I think that the recent continuous increase in the prices of BTC and ETH will generate price risks, and the stability fee (ETH\WBTC\YFI\LINK\BAT) should be appropriately increased to hedge the risks caused by price increases.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: 30M / 5% SF. No need to complicate and the 4%-6% looks fine to me. Would we be having this vote if the 11.5M user split their debt over multiple vaults? EDIT: SF percents
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Primoz:  The current structure of vaults is seen as very risky as there is one vault with 11.5m DAI debt that has only 204% collateralization (14% price drop and it gets liquidated).   While the vault would get liquidated after a 14% price drop, you’d need another 43% drop for the liquidation to resolve at a loss. 51% total drop. Binance YFI/USDT has more than $100m in daily volume. Coinbase YFI/USD has more than $35m in daily volume.  Raising the SF for the YFI-A vaults to 7% sounds like a good idea to make the interest rate more in-line with competitors. Makes sense to raise the rate closer to a market rate when the risk team doesn’t want more than 20M or 30M exposure for YFI-A.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: 30M and 6%. We have to remain competitive. We can underwrite the risk with stability buffer increases if we need to.

As I read the comments I am not sure everyone understands the option 2. Option 2 is two vault: YFI-A at 7% 20M with 175% YFI-B at 4% 20M with 225% So 40M in total. I believe the reason behind this, came from a previous post. Basically with 40M we hold 10% of YFI. Even if you have a good turnover in terms of liquidity. You don’t dump 10% of the whole supply with out moving the market. Especially when the market is already down. The idea is first to decrease the risk and smooth the dump by having a spread on the dumping via the LR and the different vault.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I think doing both 1 and 2 makes sense in the short term. I would love to see whitelisted vaults start to develop in the coming months.

I was just informed by the @Protocol-Engineering that it will not be possible to implement another YFI-B vault type by the end of this year. Which means the only other option in short term is to increase YFI-A DC to 30m and raise SF, if increasing debt exposure is preferred (so far it seems low LR vault type option has same amount of votes as 30m DC / 10% SF option). I agree that 10% SF may not be competitive enough. I am simply stating the numbers from our model, but of course our model doesn’t predict exact numbers since it is based on assumptions. If we are confident that few whales who are keeping low CR can avoid liquidations successfully all the time, risk premium is lower than 10%. On the other hand, the Rates Group can still propose lower SF next week and there is no rule that states SF needs to equal Risk Premium all the time, since RP mostly helps with guidance and is only estimated. We have actually violated this (under compensation of risk) few times this year when we kept fees very low.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: In that case I would support an increase in the DC of 10m at a 7% rate which would be slightly lower than aave so we will be in the market and also protect ourselves from the increased exposure we would be assuming

content.content: I think it would be good to start thinking about risk tranches. Open up a secondary vault with the same LR but a higher SF. Would that work from a risk perspective or does the whole supply have to be taxed the increased SF on a higher DC?

content.content: A second vault with the same LR but a higher SF doesn’t make much sense.
Why? First users get priority on lower fees while expanded supply costs extra.

I think it’s okay to be non-competitive if we’re uncomfortable with the risk. If half the vaults close their position, we’re left with 50% of the exposure and roughly the same amount of stability fees – seems like a win/win until the smart contracts team can potentially create a B-type vault to reduce liquidation exposure.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Yes, it would be a much fairer option since original vault owners don’t have to see their rates increased due to new vault owners, it would also enable more stable demand (probably). Not quite sure how complex it would be though in the short term.

content.content: Jiecut:  Raising the SF for the YFI-A vaults to 7% sounds like a good idea to make the interest rate more in-line with competitors.   I would caution against this thinking. The risk premium charged should be inline with the underlying risk (to in effect insure against losses, thus the DAI minted is “risk-less”. Market competitors should help guide what is sane, but the underlying risk premium determination should be isolated from monetary policy and other lenders.

content.content: onchain poll is live running until Thursday 16oo CET - please participate!

I don’t agree with this line of reasoning. Raising the stability fee on an asset discourages borrowing with that asset. All it will accomplish is discourage YFI holders from borrowing at Maker and possibly a marginal increase in protocol revenue. We have to decide, do we want more YFI or not? We are basically saying “please mint more Dai using YFI (by raising the DC)” then also saying “please deposit your YFI at AAVE instead (by raising the SF all the way to 10%.)”

content.content: Vaultholders are customers, too. If my bank raised my adjustable rate loan by 125% overnight I’d find a new bank. The system needs collateral, and I don’t see how these drastic movements instill any sort of borrower confidence. I absolutely understand that there is risk, but once again pushing the lever all the way in one direction seems harmful to the people the protocol needs most right now.

content.content: If enough voting weight votes for no, no change is going to be made in the next executive - also means no DC increase.

brianmcmichael:  If my bank raised my adjustable rate loan by 125% overnight I’d find a new bank.   From my lens, it all rotates around the underlying risk. If the market were 25%, I do not advocate we follow the market UNLESS the underlying risk justifies that value. The revenue from the collateral (all of them… big and small) will come. What we must instill is the discipline to only price according to the risk.

content.content: Lowering the LR of a market decreases the risk. Increasing CHOP decreases the risk. Raising the stability fee of a market does not de-risk that market. It only de-risks in the sense that borrowers are driven away from the market, contracting Dai supply. If we’re raising the SF so high in one go, we should just admit we don’t want people borrowing using YFI, and that the DC increase is a charade.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Sf raise is temporary until yfi-b vault with higher lr is in place. We want to discourage more risk through higher fees aka insurance money as it’s the only option we have this instant to increase supply and also mitigate risk.

content.content: Surplus money can come from any market, it’s not like only surplus income from the YFI market can be used to underwrite the risk from the YFI market. That’s the benefit of having a system that is diversified with many collaterals and also why I suggested a surplus buffer increase cadence. I just don’t understand why we should punish borrowers because of our timeline when we clearly have the capability to underwrite the temporary risk.

Right now the methodology is based on liquidity and price risk so that is what we are conforming to based on the limited options we have. Sure it sucks to have smaller margins of profit but the protocol comes first.

content.content: In addition to all the good suggestions for how to help out this situation, I think it’s important we recognize this situation as a failure, and learn to not repeat this kind of unnecessary self damage in the future. It should always be a top priority to avoid governance failures, so governance caused failures doesn’t become normalized and maker governance starts regularly taking action that is self damaging. I’m not saying that someone should be blamed, but I think at the time when the decision was made there was not enough focus the potential negative outcome of kicking out a lot of users, that we’ve now achieved. Risks and self damaging outcomes should always be properly analyzed and discussed when taking governance action.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I’m slightly frustrated about the pattern of Maker governance making suboptimal decisions due to being unnecessarily rigid in the governance process. From delaying setting Stablecoin fees to 0% because of some technicality in the IRV, to not polling separately for YFI DC increase and rates. We called the vault holder’s bluff, and failed. Now they took their collateral to a platform with algorithmically determined interest rates. Maybe it’s not the best for us, if we have to call our customer’s bluffs. We can regain some market share if we quickly lower the SF to a reasonable level.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
